intro: Euploca tabuliplagae, commonly known as the narrow-leaf euploca, is a rare flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pale pink. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils in open habitats such as pine flatwoods and wetlands. It is a member of the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and exhibits a C4 photosynthetic pathway, allowing it to thrive in warm, sunny environments. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is protected in several states.
